title: 104_hr971
content: The Act titled "Homeowners Empowerment and Protection Act of 1995" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 contains findings related to the Act. The Congress recognizes the importance of homeowners in preserving property value, which is influenced by the neighborhood and environment. The value of a home is linked to the quality of the neighborhood and environment, including water, air, flooding risk, scenic beauty, odors, noise, wildlife, and other factors in the United States. The value of homes in the United States can be negatively impacted by various factors such as offensive odors, excessive noise, industrial activities, and irresponsible actions of entities or individuals. It is important to protect private homeowners from these adverse effects on their property values. Protecting private homeowners from irresponsible actions that harm property values is crucial for homeowners, communities, and society as a whole. Current public information procedures often fail to notify homeowners of activities that could significantly impact their home values. Homeowners have the right to access information about activities that may reduce the value of their homes. Within 90 days of this Act's enactment, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget must establish uniform Federal procedures for agencies regarding property impacting activities. Agencies must require applicants to provide a notice as described in this section. A lead agency will be designated for applications involving multiple agencies. The Director will designate a lead agency for applications involving multiple agencies. An "application to conduct property impacting activity" refers to a request for authorization to conduct activities that may reduce the value of private homes. The notice under this section must be provided to homeowners within a 1/4 mile of the site where the activity will take place, as required by Federal law for activities that may impact property values. The applicant must provide written notice to homeowners within a 1/4 mile of the site where the activity will occur. Notice must also be published in local newspapers and mailed to homeowners likely to suffer a reduction in property value. The agency must provide notice by mail to homeowners likely to suffer a reduction in property value due to the proposed activity. The notice should describe the application, potential impacts on home values, homeowners, and the public, and provide contact information for further inquiries. The agency must notify homeowners by mail about the proposed activity's impact on property values. Homeowners can call a toll-free number to express concerns and learn about opportunities to comment on the activity. Each agency must establish a toll-free number for homeowners to register concerns about potential property value impacts and request more information on property impacting activities. Homeowners can also learn about opportunities to submit public comments. The agency allows homeowners to register concerns about property value impacts and submit public comments on property impacting activities. If a homeowner's property is likely to lose value, the agency will investigate and look for ways to minimize the impact. SEC. 4. HOMEOWNER RIGHT OF ACTION. Whenever a person carries out an activity authorized by a permit, license, or other approval that generates pollutants causing a significant reduction in the value of private homes, the homeowner can take legal action against them. If a person's activity causes a significant reduction in the value of private homes by $10,000 or more, the homeowner can sue them. Before filing a lawsuit, the homeowner must give a 30-day notice to the defendant and the relevant agency. The homeowner must deliver a notice of intent to sue to the defendant and relevant agency before filing a lawsuit for property value reduction. The agency head can convene a meeting to resolve the claim and avoid litigation costs, but the homeowner retains the right to take legal action after the 30-day notice period. In any legal action for property value reduction, the homeowner must prove that the defendant's actions caused the decrease. Homeowners with similar issues can file class action suits in federal court. The homeowner can file a lawsuit in federal court to recover the reduction in their home's value caused by certain activities, with compensation capped at the median value of nearby homes. The homeowner can file a lawsuit in federal court to recover the reduction in their home's value caused by certain activities, with compensation capped at the median value of nearby homes. If compensation is received, reasonable attorney's fees will be awarded, and injunctions may be issued for violations of Federal statutes. (g) In addition to compensation, the court may enjoin activities that violate Federal laws. (h) The US district court has jurisdiction over actions under this section. (i) Frivolous lawsuits may be dismissed if found to be abusive or harassing. The US district court has original jurisdiction over actions under this section. Frivolous lawsuits may be dismissed if found to be abusive or harassing, with the plaintiff potentially being ordered to pay the defendant's attorney's fees and expenses. No action may be brought under this section beyond the statute of limitations. The court may order the plaintiff to pay the defendant's attorney's fees and expenses in litigation. No action can be brought after 5 years or $10,000 reduction in home value. The Act does not limit other claims. The Act does not limit other claims or causes of action under the Constitution or any other law regarding real or personal property. Commencement of a suit or receipt of compensation under this Act is not a condition precedent for any other legal claim. SEC. 5. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act applies to permits, licenses, approvals issued by an agency and contracts, leases entered into after 180 days from enactment. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "agency" is defined as stated in section 551(1) of title 5, United States Code. An activity that generates pollutants or produces adverse impacts may reduce the value of a private home if it results in physical damage or unreasonable interference with its use. The term "private home" includes owner-occupied dwellings, multi-family dwellings, and condominiums. The term "private home" refers to any owner-occupied dwelling, including multi-family dwellings and condominiums. A "reduction in value" for a private home affected by certain activities is the estimated difference in fair market value caused by the activity. The term "value" refers to the difference in fair market value of a home due to certain activities. "Person" includes individuals, corporations, partnerships, or other entities excluding government agencies.
